# Lower Limb Pain Framework: Hip and Knee
## Initial map
| Region | Core entities | High-yield clue |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Lateral hip | Greater trochanteric pain syndrome | side-lying pain and focal lateral tenderness |
| Knee ligament | ACL injury | pivot mechanism + pop + rapid hemarthrosis |
| Knee meniscus | Meniscal tear | locking/catching + delayed effusion |
| Anterior knee | Patellofemoral pain syndrome | pain with prolonged sitting/stairs |
| Peri-knee bursa | Prepatellar/Pes anserine bursitis | kneeling or medial proximal tibial focal pain |

## Hip branch
- GTPS is often tendon-driven peri-trochanteric syndrome (not pure bursitis alone).
- Clinical diagnosis dominates; advanced imaging is usually for atypical/refractory cases.

## Knee triage rule
- Injury mechanism + swelling timing + instability/mechanical symptoms are the highest-yield differentiators.

# Knee Injury Patterns: ACL, Meniscus, PCL, Extensor Mechanism, and Overuse Syndromes
## ACL injury
- Pivot/deceleration mechanism with audible pop and rapid swelling from hemarthrosis.
- Exam focus: Lachman/anterior drawer; MRI confirms structural severity.

## Meniscal tear
- Twisting on planted foot with delayed swelling (12-24h) and locking/catching.
- Exam maneuvers include Thessaly/McMurray plus joint-line tenderness.

## PCL injury
- Dashboard/posterior force mechanism; posterior drawer localization.

## Extensor mechanism failure
- Inability to actively extend knee is emergency functional clue.
- Patellar tendon rupture: patella alta and palpable infrapatellar defect.
- Patellar dislocation: typically lateral displacement with reduction strategy.

## Chronic/overuse branches
- PFPS: anterior pain with prolonged sitting/stair load, often managed with quadriceps-focused rehab.
- Baker cyst can mimic DVT when ruptured; ultrasound differentiation may be required.
- Prepatellar bursitis requires septic-vs-nonseptic distinction.
- Pes anserine bursitis localizes below medial joint line and can mimic MCL/medial compartment pain.

# Rapid Recap: Knee Differential + Foot/Ankle Transition
## Differential timing table
| Condition | Trigger/mechanism | Signature sign | Swelling timing |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ACL tear | pivot/deceleration | instability + Lachman pattern | immediate hemarthrosis |
| Meniscal tear | twisting load | locking/catching | delayed (hours) |
| PCL tear | dashboard/posterior force | posterior drawer | variable |
| Patellar tendon rupture | jump-landing failure | no active extension + patella alta | early |
| PFPS | repetitive overuse biomechanics | theater sign/anterior pain | often minimal effusion |
| GTPS | lateral tendon overload | focal lateral hip tenderness | usually no major intra-articular effusion |
| Baker cyst rupture | posterior cyst leak | calf pain/swelling mimicking DVT | acute episode |

## Transition
- Next block focuses on foot/ankle pathology: heel pain patterns, Achilles disorders, stress fractures, neuromas, sprains, and Charcot foot traps.

# Foot and Ankle Pathology: Top-Down Structure and Heel Pain
## Classification tree
```
Painful foot
├── Heel pain
│   ├── Plantar surface: plantar fasciitis vs calcaneal stress injury
│   └── Posterior surface: Achilles tendinopathy/rupture, pediatric apophysitis
├── Forefoot pain
│   ├── Metatarsal stress fractures
│   └── Neuropathic lesions (Morton neuroma, tarsal tunnel)
├── Ankle trauma
│   └── Sprain imaging triage by Ottawa rules
└── Neuropathic collapse trap
    └── Charcot neuroarthropathy in diabetic neuropathy
```

## Plantar fasciitis
- Classic first-step morning pain with startup stiffness after rest.
- Clinical diagnosis predominates; heel spur on imaging is often incidental.
- Management: stretching/load modification/supportive conservative measures.

## Calcaneal stress injury
- Pain typically worsens with activity rather than easing after warm-up.
- Heel squeeze-provocation can support suspicion when early X-ray is unrevealing.

## Achilles complex
- Tendinopathy localizes to watershed region above insertion.
- Rupture clues: sudden pop and positive Thompson context, with fluoroquinolone risk associations.
- Pediatric Sever disease is usually self-limited with activity modification.

# Forefoot Syndromes, Ottawa Rules, and Charcot Foot
## Forefoot stress fractures
- Overuse and low-energy availability patterns increase risk.
- 2nd metatarsal is common stress site.
- 5th-metatarsal Jones pattern has poorer healing potential and may require operative strategy.

## Neuropathic forefoot syndromes
- Morton neuroma: interdigital burning/pebble sensation, often 3rd-4th web space.
- Tarsal tunnel: tibial nerve compression posterior to medial malleolus with plantar paresthesia distribution.

## Ottawa ankle rules (imaging triage)
- Determine need for radiographs using malleolar/midfoot bony tenderness zones and immediate/ED weight-bearing capacity.

## Charcot neuroarthropathy trap
- Diabetic neuropathy patient with warm/red/swollen foot but unexpectedly low pain severity.
- Distinguish from infection using ulcer context/evolution and imaging.
- Early off-loading (for example total-contact cast) is central treatment strategy.

# Orthopedic Trauma Framework and Upper-Limb Injuries
## Structural map
```
Orthopedic trauma
├── Upper limb injuries
│   ├── Scaphoid fracture
│   ├── Distal radius (Colles) fracture
│   ├── Pediatric supracondylar fracture
│   └── Clavicle fracture patterns
├── Lower limb/pelvic trauma
│   ├── Femoral neck fracture
│   ├── Pelvic ring injury
│   └── Stress fractures
├── Surgical emergency
│   └── Compartment syndrome
└── Post-trauma complications
    ├── CRPS
    └── Myositis ossificans
```

## Upper-limb high-yield table
| Injury | Hallmark clue | Core next step |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Scaphoid fracture | snuffbox tenderness after FOOSH | thumb-spica immobilization despite early negative X-ray |
| Colles fracture | dorsal angulation (dinner-fork profile) | reduction/cast and neurovascular monitoring |
| Supracondylar fracture | pediatric trauma with fat-pad signs | urgent neurovascular check and ortho escalation |
| Clavicle fracture (newborn) | asymmetric Moro/crepitus | conservative immobilization in uncomplicated cases |

## Key pearl
- Scaphoid and pediatric elbow injuries are frequent exam traps where delayed complications occur if initially under-treated.

# Lower-Limb Trauma and Compartment Syndrome
## Femoral neck fracture
- Typical leg shortening/external rotation pattern in older adults.
- Early operative management improves survival/mobility outcomes.

## Pelvic fracture hemodynamic priority
- Unstable pelvic injury can cause massive occult bleeding.
- Pelvic binder is immediate life-saving bridge in unstable open-book patterns.

## Stress fractures and pediatric fracture behavior
- Overuse and energy-deficit contexts drive metatarsal stress injuries.
- Pediatric greenstick/buckle patterns reflect pliable immature bone mechanics.

## Compartment syndrome emergency
| Feature | High-yield meaning |
| --- | --- |
| severe pain with passive stretch | earliest critical clinical clue |
| rising compartment pressure with low delta pressure | perfusion failure risk |
| pulselessness/paralysis | late, limb-threatening findings |

- Definitive treatment is urgent fasciotomy; delay causes irreversible ischemic injury.

# Post-Trauma Complications and Bone Pathology Transition
## Chronic exertional compartment syndrome
- Exercise-induced pressure symptoms resolving with rest; differs from acute limb-threatening syndrome.

## CRPS
- Disproportionate pain with autonomic skin/temperature/sweat changes after injury.
- Early mobilization-focused rehab is first-line; prolonged immobilization worsens course.

## Myositis ossificans
- Post-traumatic intramuscular ossification can mimic mass.
- Avoid early excision during active maturation phase.

## Amputation pain distinctions
- Stump pain, phantom limb pain, and focal neuroma pain have different timelines/localization behavior.

## Transition
- Next section moves to bone pathology core: avascular necrosis, metabolic bone disease, osteomyelitis, and tumor-pattern localization.

# Rapid Recap: Ortho Trauma and Emergency Decisions
| Scenario | Most likely condition | Next best action |
| --- | --- | --- |
| FOOSH + snuffbox tenderness, initial X-ray negative | occult scaphoid fracture | thumb-spica immobilization and repeat imaging strategy |
| Elderly FOOSH with dinner-fork deformity | distal radius (Colles) fracture | reduction/cast with neurovascular follow-up |
| Child elbow trauma + posterior fat pad sign | supracondylar fracture concern | urgent neurovascular assessment and ortho management |
| Unstable pelvic trauma | major pelvic hemorrhage risk | immediate pelvic binder + resuscitative pathway |
| Calf/limb severe pain on passive stretch after trauma | acute compartment syndrome | emergent fasciotomy pathway |
| Persistent severe post-injury pain with autonomic changes | CRPS | PT/OT-centered desensitization and mobilization |
| Post-trauma hard muscle mass | myositis ossificans | avoid early resection while lesion matures |
